newsitem.title: ZAIRE: Zaire polls to cost $253 million, seeks 60 percent.
newsitem.headline: Zaire polls to cost $253 million, seeks 60 percent.

text.p: Zaire's National Electoral Commission has estimated the budget for the country's long-awaited elections at $253 million, parliamentary sources said on Tuesday.
About 60 percent of the budget, presented to parliament for approval, is expected to be financed by foreign donors, with the government making up the remainder.
Zaire has been in talks with U.N. agencies for assistance with presidential and parliamentary elections due by next May, the country's first multi-party polls for more than 30 years.
Although approval of the budget would be a symbolic step forward in Zaire's transition to democracy now more than five years behind, the holding of elections is by no means certain.
Strongman President Mobutu Sese Seko, who has ruled Zaire since seizing power in 1965, is convalescing in Europe after surgery in August.
He says he will seek re-election and it is a foregone conclusion in Zaire that elections cannot be held behind his back. It is not clear when he will be back on his feet.
Parliament, which adopted a new federalist constitution this month further complicating election logistics in the vast country, has yet to enact an elctoral law.
"We are still waiting for the electoral law, and the president who is convalescing from surgery in Switzerland, should assure people," said a diplomat in the capital.
Many Zaireans doubt elections can be held while violence spirals uncontrollably in eastern regions suffering from a spillover of bloodshed in neighbouring Rwanda and Burundi.
